newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Zaire offers "flexibility" on refugee aid.
newsitem.headline: Zaire offers "flexibility" on refugee aid.

text.p: Zaire's Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo said on Wednesday his country was prepared to show "flexibility" to ensure that emergency food aid reached civilians and refugees fleeing a Tutsi revolt in eastern Zaire.

Kengo, speaking after talks with U.N. special envoy Raymond Chretien, said Zaire accepted the idea of a multinational force under Canadian command but stressed that protected aid corridors should be designed to ensure a return home of all refugees.
"In order to bring food supplies to the displaced and refugees, Zaire must be prepared to be flexible if necessary," Kengo told reporters after the 90-minute meeting.
Chretien paid tribute to Kengo's commitment, which followed earlier Zairean statements that any shipment of aid through rebel-held territory would violate its sovereignty.
"It's extremely important that the Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo has expressed his willingness not to use international principles as a barrier to aiding the refugees very, very quickly," he said.

Aid efforts in the east, where Tutsi rebels control a string of Zairean towns, have been complicated by Zairean accusations of territorial violations by Tutsi-led Rwanda. The U.N. and other relief agencies transported supplies into the eastern town of Goma on Monday after negotiations with the rebels.
